column1: Before 15 August 2021, will Alexei Navalny be convicted on any fraud charges related to his activities with his non-profit organizations?
column6: ['Society', 'Non-US Politics']
No.
Last working day today before question closes; nothing relevant in the news:
Not much time for this and government do not want to rise attention to his name

Russia opens new criminal case against Navalny allies - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/close-ally-kremlin-critic-navalny-leaves-russia-amid-crackdown-rt-ren-tv-cite-2021-08-08/ Tue, 10 Aug 2021 13:02:00 GMT
Navalny has been punished by Novichok& different sentences moreover Blocking his website. He is now not dangerous and Putin looks for other opponent leaders like luybov Sobol.
This forecast is based on: 1-The increasing power for Putin to deter any opponent.
There just isnt time to convict now
Time is running out.
There is not information that indicates this will happen by August 15.
We're getting close to the deadline so it's unlikely to happen this soon but it's still likely to happen overall.
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-finds-navalny-ally-sobol-guilty-breaching-covid-19-health-rules-2021-08-03/
Short timeframe, will adjust down in case no further news
Alexei Navalny has been hobbled sufficiently through the extremist organizations bill.
only two weeks to go, and it doesn't seem a conviction will occur in that time frame
lowering with the passage of time
Passage of time
Passage of time.
Time's up
Not likely.
No change.
19 days to go. Even speedy Russian trials don't start and finish so quickly.

Not hearing any news and with a month away, not likely to see something happen by August 15th. Can't rule out to 0%, still pondering if August would be a quiet time of year to start a quick trial. Or has extending the house arrest of Navalny's spokesperson until January 2022 today just determine the potential court date? https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-extends-house-arrest-kremlin-critic-navalnys-spokesperson-2021-07-21/

At this point, even a pretend trial would call more attention to Navalny than Vlad the Shirtless would prefer. The pretend elections are impending, and turning any sort of spotlight on Navalny would not likely help the cause.
updating
Passage of time
del.

There is still time for him to be poisoned while trying to escape before this Q expires, and anyway no hurry to file more charges. They already have enough charges to stage a Lewis Carroll "verdict first" trial.
Time passing , even for the Russian rule of law time critical
Not enough time to convict if in the US. Not sure about the process in Russia so, technically, I guess it's still a (remote) possibility.

A month seems to be not a lot for conviction given that he hasn't been indicted yet. Nevertheless, previous comments + his position (past criticisms and trials etc.) suggests that it's not that unlikely.

I'm reverting back to my initial forecast. I don't think they do anything major ahead of the State Duma elections on 19 September. This is a sensitive matter as we've seen by the many protests across RU. It seems that labeling Navalny's organization 'Extremist' has already seriously restricted his network for now, barring the members from seeking office. No need to push further IMO, at least in the coming months.
There appears not enough time to reach a conviction
Navalny hasn't even been indicted yet, they've only opened an investigation. Any trial going to happen hasn't even started. There is simply not enough time.
I reduced from 10% to 5%. Unlikely that anyone is going to do anything with this case.
This situation seems to have a little quiet recently. The clock is ticking on this one and would seem that time is starting to run out. Still a month and a half to go, but seems unlikely.

Kremlin critic Navalny discloses details of 'extremism' ruling - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/kremlin-critic-navalny-discloses-details-extremism-ruling-2021-06-23/ Wed, 23 Jun 2021 14:59:00 GMT
-4 for passage of time
Back to my original stance of a low probability event.
International political pressure is too high.

Navalny mocks Putin over accusation he consciously left in a coma - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/navalny-mocks-putin-over-accusation-he-consciously-left-coma-2021-06-17/ Thu, 17 Jun 2021 14:05:00 GMT

My 8 ball says, "Don't Count on It." The accepted judicial system around the world, is based on the facts and judicial evidence. From what I read and seen in the news, it's more like a circus in Russia. Alexei Navalny, must fight the fight even if the road is long. As for President Putin, if he truly want to control decent in Russia, he must isolate Russia from the world, like Kim Jong Un of North Korea isolates North Korea from the World. Zero probablity "0%" to this question.
revised estimate

The Kremlin is operating in a more subtle manner destroying political adversaries' reputation, via the Telegram-katyusha organized by a Putin friend called Wladislaw Kljuschin. https://pledgetimes.com/2021/06/disinformation-why-america-is-demanding-the-extradition-of-a-russian-businessman/
Fraud charges are superfluous now that Navalny and his organization are extremists.

Wed, 02 Jun 2021 07:00:00 GMT Biden 'Won't Hold Back': Jen Psaki Shuts Down Putin Spox Who Says Navalny Won't Come Up At Summit - Newsweek https://www.newsweek.com/biden-wont-hold-back-jen-psaki-shuts-down-putin-spox-who-says-navalny-wont-come-summit-1600105
He is half dead, rotting away in a penal colony. Fraud charges will attract scrutiny that Putin does not want.
revised estimate

okay, so yesterday the court ruled Navalny's group as "extremist". https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/09/world/europe/navalny-ban-putin-biden-summit.html I agree that it could be a signal to Biden. I still believe no major decision will be taken on Navalny's group before the legislative election coming up, considering that they cannot predict how it could play on public, and it can in fact backfire. I'll increase my probability estimate for now, but I still stand with my original decision.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/09/russian-court-expected-to-outlaw-alexei-navalnys-organisation Fraud can be next

Unless I'm missing something it doesn't seem like his current trial is for fraud with his non-profits. Those charges seem to still be an investigation like they were in December (https://sledcom.ru/news/item/1526952/). There's been no updates out of Sledcom about charges, and the most recent news seems to suggest they're still just probes (https://www.dw.com/en/russia-alexei-navalny-says-he-is-facing-three-new-probes/a-57654608). The current trial is for his non-profit being branded an extremist organization (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/09/russian-court-expected-to-outlaw-alexei-navalnys-organisation), and before that for slander of a veteran (https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20210212-kremlin-critic-navalny-back-in-moscow-court-for-slander-trial). The time from charges to trial is several months historically (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1243774), and we're not even at charges yet.
His return to Pokrow could mean that he appears fit for trial.
Doesn't seem like it will happen in the time remaining
sad and hopefully not true
revising estimate
75 days to go!

Further efforts by the Kremlin to silence Navalny and his organization. If this bill goes through, which it likely will, they won't need to convict them of fraud, they'll simply call them extremists and shut down everything.
Court proceedings can start very quickly for political prisoners in Russia and end very quickly with a conviction. In two weeks, for example, he could be charged and convicted of fraud.
updating to account for the passage of time.
Still do not think there is enough time to file charges, hold a trial, and have a conviction before August 15th.
there is no rush in to do so
need to adjust dramtically , since surprisingly the state authorities open up new cases instead of letting the issues rest
Adjusting 50 to 60% given new news of investigations into his foundation. Given his past and current judicial treatment, I forecast a conviction on at least 1 charge related to his foundation.

Navalny reports [0] that yesterday he talked with an investigator (of particularly important cases — this is an official title :-) about 3 cases again him: fraud, extremism, and insult to a judge. The last one hasn't been known to the public.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/russias-navalny-fights-to-stay-in-public-eye-in-putin-standoff-11621771200
Chances are getting slimmer and slimmer since trials take time.
Adjusting upwards, considering @yagudin's very interesting rationale: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1280072
In light of new developments [0] [1], I moved from ~8% to ~20%.
I don't think anything serious happens before the election. Focus is to block Navalny's network and the upcoming election. Considering the recent protests, best strategy for Kremlin is to play along.
As far as I understand, the witnesses were also questioned about the "extremist" organization case: https://twitter.com/ioannZH/status/1395012653836349441
The prosecution started to question the witnesses: https://twitter.com/ioannZH/status/1394910975271317504

Russian prosecutor submits more material in Navalny 'extremism' case - lawyers - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russian-prosecutor-submits-more-material-navalny-extremism-case-lawyers-2021-05-17/ Mon, 17 May 2021 09:04:00 GMT
Summer break
Going down. In particular, I expect Russian courts to take a vacation in summer
To short a time frame

Timeline is too short, and no apparent motive for a significant deviation from past procedure. Formal charges still haven't been brought. The prior arguments I'd had in favor were to discredit before parliamentary elections, but they've just chosen to jail him and attempt to shut down his non-profit group instead (https://www.npr.org/2021/04/26/990824453/russian-court-suspends-alexei-navalnys-anti-kremlin-network), so there's little chance of that happening. Jailing may also fit with their desire to not give him his much desired media attention, and if that's their main plan of action then giving him a trial where he or someone else can defend him would be a poor choice.

There is no rule of law in Russia other than the rule of Putin, oppose Putin and your are toasted like breakfast bread with lots of grease. The courts in Russia are a kangoroo shows, so yes they will throw the book at Nalvany including his involvement in the conspiracy for the sun to rise every morning.
His health is getting worse. His enemies want to drive down interest in a possible investigation after his death.
I just hope he lives long enough
he is fighting back with his hunger strikes
For the reasons nicely wrapped-up by @yagudin [1], @Dustin-MacDonald [2][3], and @slapthepancake [4], I don't think this is likely to happen within the time context set in the question.
Time is really short till the 15th August to end a trial and convict Navalny.
At this point looks increasingly unlikely. He is also in bad health.
See data, analysis by @derberkerl at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1270381
Maybe the government finds it more useful to hold the charges over his head than actually present them in public. Especially if the facts don't support the charges

105 days until this question resolves. Russia must initiate a trial before December 29 2021 (241 days), see Sergei Magnitsky. In order for this question to resolve they must start AND FINISH the trial in the next 105 days. I just don't see it.
Still on the low side because I need to find evidence of a trial, which does not seem to be on the cards right now.

Looks like they've decided to accuse him and his buddies of being terrorists. That outranks fraud, and has the additional charm of justifying a death penalty. He may still not live to see a trial, of course, but Lewis Carroll had it right either way: “No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”

Criminal proceedings were initiated today against Navalny and his comrades-in-arms for founding an association for violence against citizens or other damage. This can happen very quickly, just as all his organizations are caught in a wave of repression.
The russian "courts" ruled against his non profit organisation on the basis of "extremism".
it looks like Russia is going a different route to crackdown on his organizations.
Looks less like they will be charged with fraud as opposed to being charged with being terrorists.

I had to lower my estimate since his non-profit organizations have been shot down as effective immediately please see the following link : https://www.euronews.com/2021/04/26/russian-court-orders-alexei-navalny-s-anti-corruption-foundation-to-suspend-activities 29th of April will show if I am right I believe the court will close the case of the foundation and thus the posted question following the direction not of "fraund" but "extremism" - as suggested by the public prosecutors office. Lets see and wait

Still possible he will die in prison, despite ending his hunger strike. For Putin, having Navalny die in prison would be easier and less public than holding a trial. Ending the hunger strike greatly increase the possibility that he will be tried and found guilty, but despite the speediness of Russian courts when Putin wants something, it remains unlikely that Navalny will be convicted before August 15th. Additionally, Putin needs the global community to be distracted by something else before holding a trial for Navalny.
Russia will delay this as he is jailed anyway to keep global coverage about him on a lower level.
He is unlikely to be alive.
He gonna die

Holding onto my bet that he will join the Choir Invisible before this question ends. Unluckily for Vlad the Shirtless, Navalny has called off his hunger strike, so he will now probably have to commit suicide by stabbing himself in the back while trying to escape. He's still not well, of course, so they could catch a break and he could die of kidney failure, induced by being shot several times in the kidney. KGB alumni are not famous for subtlety.

Current actions seem to suggest Putin's plays for support are around flexing military muscle in Ukraine and making up plots against Russia and its allies by the West like he did with Lukashenko. His approval rankings plummeted to 27% (https://www.economist.com/briefing/2021/04/24/vladimir-putin-is-growing-ever-more-repressive-as-he-loses-support) in the wake of Navalny's poisoning and imprisonment and the ensuing protests, so it seems like efforts at vilifying him and giving him attention have been detrimental to Putin. The timeframe for this question was already drastically shorter than would normally be expected for a lawsuit there, and recent actions make a rushed investigation and trial further less likely.

He ended his hunger strike so maybe he won't die in jail before August. Going back to my original rationale, I'm not sure what Putin gets from convicting Navanlny that he doesn't get by just leaving him in jail.
Increasing because he is ending hunger strike. Still feel it is unlikely in the timeframe involved.
He is likely to die first.

Reducing forecast based on increased international attention to this whole issue. Not trying to be cavalier, but Navalny is so sick right now that his death is on the precipice. This mess is turning out to be bad for business, so to speak.
Note to self: For better forecasting, don't wait until the crowd catches up and passes your forecast.
I don't see any reason to try him if he is going to die in prison.

Increasing in light of the lawsuit filed last week against Navalny’s anti-corruption campaign (https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiELkA166E1SipTwjJowgP_0gqFQgEKg0IACoGCAowrqkBMKBFMJGBAg?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen)
Navalny is now hospitalized and may die before he is released. Additionally, foreign pressure is increasing, making a conviction within his timeframe less likely.

Low chance. Even if he does not die in prison, they will find a way to keep him away from the media or trump up some other charges. The non-profit itself might be dismantled though, and as we've seen, several supporters are already detained. However, Putin is concerned with showing people that the grass is not necessarily so green on the other side, and might trial Navalny regardless of his condition (even in absentia through death), just to show that he (too) is corrupt.
tragically, it's not looking likely that he will live long enough to be charged

Navalny will almost certainly die in prison. The international outrage for his release is almost certainly not strong enough versus Putin's will to stomp out opposition, The real question is, what is the short term impact, if any, on Putin's regime? Navalny faces a high probability of not making it out of prison alive, but that could have major consequences for Putin.
Now looking like Mr. Navalny will not survive to be charged, which is tragic and infuriating.
I don´t think Kreml sees (possible) perish and death of Navalny a big issue. They are targeting now other people... Since he is now in poor condition, -6p

tHEY'LL HAVE TO HURRY - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ol_KL69MihQ

Russian justice will of course convict him if he is still alive. If he is dead they MAY still convict him (they have convicted the dead in the past). But that is so absurd that there is some is a possibility that if he is dead they will not proceed against him.

With his health and lack or care from the government/prison system, it would appear more likely for his health to fail than to prosecute him for crime when he is still doing time for his last conviction.

Sadly Mr. Navalny´s Health conditions are deteriorating enourmously. The authorities will not see the necessity to prosecute and bring an item to publicity that will take care unfortunately of itself. I need to adjust downward

Health concerns

Navalny already has a sentence, so there is no rush. Kreml doesn't like the ongoing protests towards the elite. They want to play it down, as well as wait the European "hysteria" go pass.

The current plan is for him to die in prison of natural causes, such as having no food or sleep or medical care. Shouldn't take much longer, but if he shows signs of lingering he can always be shot at extremely close range while trying to escape, or commit suicide by stuffing some rags down his throat and up his nose, then tying himself up so he can't change his mind and remove them.

Rising slightly because Biden has rewarded Putin's threats on Ukraine. Putin can do what he wants with Navalny in that no serious consequences. Still won't want to unduly stoke domestic protests and that the main driver.

With hunger strike not sure gouvernement will be looking at the fraud charges. They should be more concerned with the potential martyr status looming.

Does he even have the health to stand trial? Even if he is taken to trial, I can see a dragged out debate about his treatment and health. Additionally, Germany has close ties to Russia and it makes sense that he was in Germany being treated back to health so that Russia could have him back and behind bars. At least it's a hypothesis. He reportedly has respiratory issues which is eerily consistent with a past rationale of mine. Maybe my mental model is working for this particular question.
His health is failing, so I think it is much more likely he will die before further charges are brought.

I would agree with others that this will be a similar outcome to Magnitsky, who died while in custody prior to any trial. From reports, Navalny's condition appears to be worsening and there is little reason for the Russian government to speed along the proceedings.

His condition continues to deteriorate. Comparison class, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergei_Magnitsky. Having failed to poison Navalny to death, the Kremlin will likely fall back on its Magnitsky tactic. Note that I am not forecasting Navalny's death before 15 Aug. 2021 but rather a factor making it less likely that the Kremlin would have to waste effort and incite blowback via a fake fraud trial.
Would appear to have reduced over time and being allowed to play out over time.

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/7/amnesty-international-says-russia-may-be-slowly-killing-navalny It looks like the current plan is for him to wither away--like Marx said the state would do, remember?
I'm wondering how his recent hunger strike will factor into his future.
They are likely to kill him now that he can't get emergency help like when they tried poisoning him.
His hunger strike and deteriorating health will likely result in his death

So far the factors point towards an early death or that there is little need for this given the existing pressures. Setting at 20% to account for potential changes to the situation internally to Russian politics.
-1 Passage of time update
He's already in jail...why not convict him of further crimes in order to keep him there!
No idea on habits and regulation regarding time periods before the conviction needs to be given, but the regime probably wants to delay as long as possible.

Navalny is reportedly being held at a prison colony 60 miles from Moscow that is said to excel at isolating inmates from the outside world, but his lawyers appear to have some degree of contact. His lawyers claim they have seen Navalny, where he has deteriorating health with his weight down to 85kgs; his declared hunger strike due to a lack of medical treatment must have contributed to this. The secretary general of Amnesty International, Agnes Callamard wrote Navalny is being subjected a slow death. A Kremlin spokesman stated that Navalny was not entitled to any special treatment. I will suggest that Navalny’s health either by the imposed conditions or self-harm will not improve in the near future and that a conviction for fraud will not happen this year.
The extra attention, of late, may be a bit restraining. The main gain of a trail, likely mostly under wraps, would be to disrupt the organization.
Putin has not stepped down on his campaign against Navalny yet he gains little from the convictions. Likely, more criticism. While it is possible, not likely before 15th of August of 2021.
He's already in prison for 2 years, message is already delivered, his condition is not well and putin doesn't want a martyr. Small chance it happens prior August 2021

Russia allows for posthumous trials. I am assuming that Russia's main objective is to get rid of Navalny's memory to whatever extent they can, so a public trial would not serve him well. If, however, they can tarnish his memory, it may serve them well.

Navalny is reportedly not well at all, so the authorities are said to be moving him to a more secure facility where he will not be bothered by reporters, or his lawyer, or his family, or any prison employees bringing him food, water, or medicine. This kind consideration will not, alas, improve his condition. He may still be convicted of things, albeit posthumously, to demonstrate that Vlad the Shirtless is unflagging in his pursuit of justice. Stay tuned.

While I have no doubt Putin wants to punish Navalny for exposing his corruption and sparking nationwide protests, but he is already in prison for 2.5 years from Feb-2021, so there is no need to hurry a trial to keep him in prison. With some Russian elections coming up, it probably is in Putin's interest to let some of the heat of the street protests die down before holding a show trial and trying to silence Navalny more permanently. 97% he will be (show) tried and convicted, but unlikely it will happen before August 15.

Seems he is refusing food now. Not sure exactly how that will impact the likelihood of conviction by the middle of August, but I still feel it's going to require uncharacteristically hurried legal action to make it happen.

I continue to believe the crowd is drastically over-estimating this one on the basis of the time horizon. Navalny was charged December 29 2020. The question ends August 15 2021 (230 days.) Mikhail Borisovich Khodorkovsky was arrested for fraud in October 2003 and convicted in May 2005.
Putin is determined to make him pay, especially since he survived an assassination attempt clearly authorized by Putin.
'Russian opposition leader' and 'conviction' sounds like something I've heard before.

Navalny is in prison due to the enforcement of a previous suspended sentence. 2.5 years from Feb 2021 The best info I can find on the new charges are here https://meduza.io/en/feature/2021/01/01/the-latest-case-against-mr-navalny So the question is will these charges get to court and lead to a conviction before mid August. In theory other charges could also be laid. The Russian criminal code https://www.legislationline.org/documents/action/popup/id/8917 suggests they are supposed to get on with it

There may not be free and fair elections but Putin is too smart to do it before Federal Duma election. He will wait until after.Then again perhaps he will do it in contravention of US and NATO and EU sanctions
Putin's already got him imprisoned for almost 3 more years, so there's no real hurry to convict right now.
Putin new level
Putin must walk this VERY carefully, too many Russians like Navalny. His hunger strike mihght add some more strength to his campaign.
Kremlin does not need a martyr before elections. He will be convicted after September.
Change: -4

Reducing conviction probability to 40% due to Alexey's worsening health conditions and the recently announced hunger strike. While conviction still fits the Kremlin narrative, the ongoing global attention and internal social unrest is intensifying. Kremlin may take a break from convictions just to lower his profile.
With the world watching, the appearance of an investigation might take more time

It doesn't take long to mount and conclude an evidence-free trial, but Vlad the Shirtless may have decided the current crop of charges is enough figleaf, and it will be easier for everyone if Navalny is accidentally poisoned while trying to escape or commits suicide by shooting himself in the back. Several times.

There is 25% chance given the expected narrative in the past has worked against the regime. The most expected case the regime can file to discredit Alexei is fraud charges, which will only fuel more protests.
given his treatment i think its more likely he'll die or be unfit to stand trial
The world is watching. Biden has made some strong comments against Putin regarding this issue. Putin will want to justify his actions and build a case
Low probability given the August timeframe. My assumption is that the Russian Government isn't in a rush to convict him.
I've used Base Rates

Following the excellent reasoning of @yagudin, I am forecasting a low likelihood of conviction before August. It also seems to me that it would best serve the interests of Putin to wait until Navalny is almost finished with his two year sentence to convict him again. I can’t imagine anything more demoralizing to Navalny personally and to his supporters.

My proposition that he may be faced with a threat to his health has come to forefront, according to recent reports. But I will hold off from dropping too much because of the frequent scenario where prisoners have decreased health, actual or only self-proclaimed. This may be a tactic because the prisoner sees impending doom. He is already doomed so it may be because of the current charges. If this degradation of health is due to an inside knowledge that another conviction is looming, then this question may resolve in yes. However, COVID-19 and prisons do not fare well together.

More likely outcome is that Navalny will be 'swapped' for the completion of NordStream 2 gas pipeline. He will be reported ill or seriously ill, then taken to (most likely) Germany for a medical check-up and then (surprise, surprise) the NS2 pipeline will be completed WITHOUT US sanctions.

It seems like he is being left in a prison to be ignored/hopefully forgotten about (from Putin's perspective), and bringing him to trial on new charges by the end of August isn't that likely. The criminal justice system is entirely controlled by the government, so if they want it to happen then it will, but there has been a couple of months with no movement on this and the deadline for this question is only 4.5 months away.
He is in poor health and his life is at risk. The justice system is not independent. There are political implications to any conviction or other decision.
Doubt he will survive to be charged
Putin's past behavior suggests that he will stop at nothing to discredit Navalny. No real indication of independence of Russian judiciary.

It is unlikely that there will be new charges by the cut-off date. Closer to his prison release date then it might be a higher probability. For now he is were the regime want him and they will be reluctant to give him more publicity opportunities at this stage, I would suggest.
this is a very specific scenario so i think the base probability is low. there are many ways to get rid of Navalny and so the sum probability of the rest of the scenarios is much higher
Reducing probability to 60% to account for Navalny's health issues which may delay new convictions
Without international intervention, it is most likely that Navalny will either be convicted or killed in prison.
Thanks for your forecast @artisan
Putin is gonna do it, but when?
Why would Putin want to give Navalny closure and provoke opposition at same time?

Putin's regime is personally interested in extension of Navalny's imprisonment indefinitely. His recent activities have created a lot of pain (including additional international sanctions and political unrest). The current imprisonment term ends right before the next presidential campaign starts in early 2024. So Kremlin has every incentive to extend it using any of the open investigations, including the one related to the non-profit fraud charges. On the matters related to Navalny and political opposition in general, Investigative Committee and courts in Russia are always consistent with the party line; the legal side of the matters is irrelevant. This was the case ever since the Yukos case and Khodorkovsky imprisonment in 2003. So overall probability of additional convictions is close to a 100%. What reduces probability is the August-15 deadline: there is no specific reason to have him convicted this summer; next year is fine too. Kremlin will carefully monitor the internal protest activity and pragmatically course correct. If Navalny's team is able to pull-off a national-level rally in the next few months (they aspire for a half million people) it may delay additional convictions.
Reports of his failing health seem to indicate he may not make it to trial.

Decreasy probability to 50% on thre basis of his alarming current health crisis. How easy it would be for Putin's people to arrange for Navalny to die in this particularly harsh prison camp. I will be follwoing this closely.
No notable movement in crowd forecast and no new news...makes me think that each day that goes by, the probability of a conviction decreases

There are only 21 weeks until August 15 2021 and Covid has slowed down all the bureaucracies which would include the criminal justice system. Given how long his previous cases took I don't think the case will even be complete before 15 August 2021.
I think that they just sentenced him and there is not too much of additional benefit to sentence him now till 15th of August.

So this breaks down into a couple questions, which are: will a ruling on the charges come before the deadline, and will the decision be to convict. The second question is basically a freebie, 100% yes. It's a show trial and he's been tried and convicted for similar crimes twice before, and the acquittal rate in Russian criminal trials is hilariously low, 0.25% as of 2019 (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/russia-justice-system-low-acquittal-rate-uk-crown-court-a8935016.html). Previous cases seem to have been geared towards discrediting him and having the conviction bar him from running for public offices, both of which the Kremlin would still have an interest in. If a ruling is brought, it's unlikely that it would be to acquit an enemy of the state for crimes similar to ones he's already been convicted of, especially when acquittal is absurdly rare in trials in general. The practice that the Russian legal system seems to prefer to acquittals is suspension of prison sentences (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suspended_sentence#Russia) like Navalny received in his previous cases. If charges are brought it's almost certain that they'll result in a conviction, with any mitigation done through a sentence suspension.

My opinion is that Navalny will not be convicted on any fraud charges before 15 August 2021, concerning his organisations and the rationale is as follows:- I will suggest that there is a blueprint here being played out that would explain the current situation. The blueprint was established by the experience of Mikhail Khodorkovsky where is was further charged of committing fraud during his initial prison sentence. Mr. Khodorkovsky was not particularly popular in the country but was one the wealthiest individual in Russia at the time. His mis-judgment was that he involved himself in politics, against the government, that he had been warned against. The second fraud case extended his imprisonment in a distant penal colony. Alexei Navalny has been despatched to a penal colony from the maximum-security prison in the Moscow area. The government may have been dismayed by the size of the demonstrations where Navalny was used as a figure head for protests in general against the administration. Navalny has become a high-profile personality and perhaps a further fraud case brought at this time would perhaps result in further demonstrations and comment in the foreign press. Using Khodorkovsky as an example, a further fraud case would make sense when the publicity dies down and the demonstrations exhaust themselves in the next two or two and half years prior to his release on the initial prison sentence. Amnesty International have probably diminished Navalny’s case by downgrading his status form one of ‘prisoner of conscience’ due to his anti-migrant racist comments made some ten years ago.

Navalny was quickly arrested upon his return to Russia after receiveing treatment in Germany for his poisoning. In December Russia charged Navalny with three new fraud charges as reported by the BBC: "Russian state investigators have brought new charges against opposition leader Alexei Navalny. They say Mr Navalny, who is convalescing in Germany after being poisoned, fraudulently spent public donations on his personal needs. Russia's Investigative Committee, which deals with serious crimes, accuses Mr Navalny of spending more than $4.8m (£3.55m) of public donations to his organisations on personal acquisitions. It says he used the funds to acquire property, buy material goods and pay for expenses such as overseas travel."
